en: Interview with Kathryn Ellis, a lawyer with Legal Aid of East Tennessee. Ellis recounts the assistance that her organization was able to provide to individuals after the wildfires. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "A big thing that we have to deal with after a disaster is how do you go about getting all of these important documents that you need. And so we would talk to them about their individual situation. We would talk to them about, was it a private landlord or was it subsidized housing, some sort of government funding? Because again, law's different. So, we would go through all of those sorts of questions and help give them the direction of--of what they needed to do or what their options were."

And so we would talk to them about their individual situation. We would talk to them about, was it a private landlord or was it subsidized housing, some sort of government funding? Because again, law's different. So, we would go through all of those sorts of questions and help give them the direction of--of what they needed to do or what their options were."

Will you state your name and what your role role at your law firm is?
How long have you been doing this legal work?
When did you first become aware of the fire in Gatlinburg?
Almsot immediately after the fire, calls began coming in to Legal Aid?
What kind of issues were you receiving calls about at that time?
So the first wave of calls were from attorneys, why would they call other attorneys for help?
After anticipating all the coming problems, when did your group start getting responses from clients?
At what point after the fire did you start receiving calls from clients with problems?
What went on in these first meetings with clients?
When did you begin moving into legal issues with clients?
How did your group proceed to work through the issues with your clients and landlords?
Can you describe your clients' frame of mind while you were seeing them?
Can you give us the magnitude, in number, of clients that you were seeing in this first wave?
At any point during this, did your clinic represent a client inside of a courtroom?
What was the expectations on the landlords in these situations?
Did you work with a lot of undocumented immigrants? Did you worry about protecting them?
As you were gaining more clients, what did you see in Gatlinburg throughout the year?
Were you surprised at how many people were taking advantage of the situation with shoddy work and practices?
How extensive was the problem for low income individuals and families not being able to find housing after the rebuilding began?
As Gatlinburg rebuilt, what did your attorneys continue to do, and when did it begin to trail off?
Can you describe what the impact of this fire was on the City of Gatlinburg?
Do you think Gatlinburg did a good job of reassessing when they came back?
Is there anything good that came out of this fire from your perspective?
Is there anything good that came out of this fire from your perspective?
Do you think that Gatlinburg will get another fire like this in the future?
Are there any similarities between the recovery of the fire in Gatlinburg and the current corona virus?

seo.title: Interview with Kathryn Ellis, 2020-05-14 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
